claim: Africa is the continent, not the country, with the most poverty.

supporting.text: Africa has the highest number of people living in extreme poverty, with over 400 million individuals below the poverty line, according to World Bank data.

attacks.text: Africa has the highest number of people living in extreme poverty, with over 400 million individuals below the poverty line, according to World Bank data.
The World Bank's poverty line definition may not account for regional cost-of-living differences, potentially overestimating poverty in Africa.
Other continents like Asia have larger total populations, so percentage-based poverty measures might be more accurate for comparison.
The World Bank adjusts its poverty thresholds for purchasing power parity, addressing cost-of-living concerns.
Even by percentage measures, Sub-Saharan Africa still shows the highest poverty rates globally.

supporting.text: The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) ranks many African countries among the lowest in the Human Development Index (HDI), reflecting widespread poverty.

attacks.text: The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) ranks many African countries among the lowest in the Human Development Index (HDI), reflecting widespread poverty.
The HDI measures more than just poverty; it includes education and life expectancy, which may not directly correlate with poverty rates.
Even if HDI includes other factors, low HDI scores in African countries strongly correlate with high poverty rates, as confirmed by World Bank data.
Some non-African countries, like Haiti and Yemen, have extreme poverty levels comparable to the poorest African nations, challenging the claim's exclusivity.
While some non-African countries have high poverty, Africa has the highest concentration of low-income countries globally, supporting the original claim.

supporting.text: Sub-Saharan Africa, in particular, has the highest poverty rate globally, with more than 40% of its population living on less than $1.90 per day.

attacks.text: Sub-Saharan Africa, in particular, has the highest poverty rate globally, with more than 40% of its population living on less than $1.90 per day.
The $1.90 per day poverty line is outdated and does not account for cost-of-living variations across regions.
Other regions, such as parts of South Asia, also have extreme poverty rates comparable to Sub-Saharan Africa.
The World Bank's 2015 update to $1.90 accounts for purchasing power parity (PPP), making it a globally comparable metric.
While South Asia has high poverty, Sub-Saharan Africa still leads in both poverty rate and depth according to most recent data.

supporting.text: Economic disparities and lack of infrastructure in many African nations contribute to persistent poverty, unlike any single country matching this scale.

attacks.text: Economic disparities and lack of infrastructure in many African nations contribute to persistent poverty, unlike any single country matching this scale.
Some countries like India or Bangladesh have poverty levels comparable to African nations, challenging the uniqueness of Africa's poverty scale.
Poverty in India or Bangladesh is concentrated in specific regions, whereas Africa's poverty is continent-wide, reinforcing the original claim.
Global poverty metrics often exclude non-monetary factors like social safety nets, which may understate poverty in non-African countries.
Even with non-monetary factors, Africa consistently ranks lowest in multidimensional poverty indices, supporting the claim.

supporting.text: Comparative studies by international organizations consistently identify Africa as the continent with the most severe and widespread poverty challenges.

attacks.text: Comparative studies by international organizations consistently identify Africa as the continent with the most severe and widespread poverty challenges.
Some studies suggest that poverty in parts of Asia, particularly South Asia, is equally severe when measured by absolute numbers rather than percentages.
International organizations often use different methodologies and definitions of poverty, which can lead to varying conclusions about which continent has the most poverty.
Africa's poverty is often highlighted due to its high-profile humanitarian crises, but other continents have chronic poverty that receives less media attention.
The focus on Africa may also reflect historical biases in international development priorities rather than purely objective measures of poverty.
